V is often seen as a residual, but in a recession it is rather more active. When spending crashes, the velocity of money slows considerably. Unless M increases, Y and/or P necessarily fall. This is simple arithmetic.

Furthermore, we know that the other two terms in the MV=PY equation can also change. Y is GDP. It crashed in 2008 along with broad M. Topping up M with QE wasn't enough to stop Y falling, let alone cause prices to rise. That was in large part because V collapsed.
If you want to see what happens when private money collapses and the central bank DOESN'T step in to compensate with public money, go look at Greece.
In the bank crisis, M (broadly defined) actually fell, a lot. QE topped it up to some extent, thus preventing a major depression due to money supply collapse as happened in the 1930s.

So a better measure of money in the MV=PY equation is M2, which includes the bank deposits and other forms of credit that most people use as money. Problem is that means accepting that bank credit can be money, contrary to Austrian economics.

The trouble is that in advanced countries today, physical cash is only about 3% of money in circulation. And because of QE, banks have more reserves than they need to settle deposit withdrawals. Money multiplier is broken.(It never really existed anyway, but that's another story)

If we use M0 (physical cash + bank reserves), we are assuming 1) physical cash is a significant proportion of money in circulation 2) there is a direct relationship between bank reserved and purchasing power, what we usually call the money multiplier""
However, the definition of M is complicated by the fact that there are several measures of M. Which one to use?

If we take the standard quantity theory of money", MV=PY, clearly if Y and V remain unchanged, P will increase if M increases. This is the assumption made by those who equate inflation with money supply increase."

It's clear however that you don't understand what the money supply" is, nor what inflation is. M0 is not the money supply. And inflation is not, and never has been, simply increase in M0, except in the imagination of Austrian economists."

I hope this analysis clarifies the situation. I don't aim to undermine or silence whistleblowers, and I am no friend to big banks. I seek only to establish the truth.
Subsequent events do show that he was right to complain about the nature of the HFC Bank contract, although there is considerable difference of opinion about the scale of overcharging.
He does reveal that the employer refused to discuss the legality or otherwise of the HFC Bank contract at the mediation hearing.
There was a mediated settlement of his employment dispute, the nature of which he does not reveal as it is covered by a confidentiality agreement. It did not include reinstatement.

He did pursue a case for unfair dismissal. Requiring someone to do work they object to on principle could be construed as constructive dismissal, so he may have had a case. However, it appears the case went to mediation.

But the fact remains that if you refuse to do the work you are employed to do, and the employer cannot find other suitable work for you to do, your employment will be terminated, probably in the form of redundancy. That, I'm afraid, is the nature of employment contracts.

Refusing to do work he considered illegal is of course entirely right and just. My analysis is in no way intended to be a criticism. I very much admire people who will put their employment at risk on a point of principle.

Thus my conclusion is that although the fact that he objected to the work he was being expected to do was a cause (perhaps the primary cause) of the dispute with his employer, his job was terminated because he refused to do the work, not because he complained to the Law Society.

He also states in a subsequent blogpost that he was made redundant, not dismissed. This suggests that the primary cause of the termination of his employment was his refusal to do the work he was employed to do. If the employer could not redeploy him, redundancy was inevitable.

He refused to return to work on that basis, and wrote a letter to the Law Society alleging the employer was guilty of malpractice. It is clear from that letter that he hoped the Law Society's involvement would prevent the employer dismissing him.

I would hazard a guess that at that point the employer terminated his sick leave and told him he must return to work. Returning to work would mean doing the work he was employed to do, including work that he objected to.

So the picture appears to be one of a long-running dispute. However, it escalated after the employer paid for him to see a psychiatrist. The psychiatrist reported that he was not very ill and could return to work.
The tone of employer communications suggests a considerable degree of exasperation on their side. His employment was evidently already at risk at the time he went off sick.

He does not reveal the full nature of that dispute, though he gives the impression that the dispute was entirely about the HFC Bank contract. The extracts from employer communications he has published appear to suggest there may have been other matters too.
Reading through the material he has published on his blog reveals that he was in dispute with his employer over the terms of his employment 10 months before he reported them to the Law Society.

The forwarders can be regarded as full-reserve banks. Because they must forward payments in advance of receiving funds, they cannot handle payments larger than, or totalling more than, their own reserves. So heavy traffic could render a forwarder unresponsive, surely?

Risk that a payment fails because forwarder becomes unresponsive in the middle of a payment chain is Herstatt risk, now largely eliminated from mainstream payments systems. As payment fails can have serious welfare consequences, reintroducing Herstatt risk is not progress.
Also, the fact that there are multiple possible payment paths does not necessarily mean the network would be distributed. A hub-and-spoke structure can have multiple payment paths.

So an open border between UK and Ireland has NOT existed for 94 years. It has existed for barely 20 years, and both countries have been EU members for all of that time.
But then came the Troubles, and twenty years of a closed and heavily policed border.

But even after that, the customs border remained, and Ireland continued to impose tariffs to protect certain industries until 1960. From 1960 onwards, the tariff barriers were progressively dismantled. By 1973, when Ireland joined the EEC, UK & Ireland had free trade.

The trade war was eventually ended in 1938 when Ireland agreed to settle land annuity claims with a one-off payment, Britain ceded the disputed Treaty Ports to Ireland, and both sides lowered tariffs.

The trade war started in 1932 when Eamon de Valera imposed high import tariffs to protect Irish agriculture during the Depression and defaulted on land annuity payments to Britain. Britain retaliated by imposing even higher import tariffs. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Trade_War …
